abstract.p: Rob Ackerman letter on Jesse McKinley's September 24 article agrees with fellow playwrights that writing itself, not recognition, provides greatest satisfaction (S)

block.p: When Signature Theater honors a single writer over an entire season, it bestows a sort of Olympian status on that individual. Jesse McKinley interviewed five of these chosen dramatists [''A Reunion of Playwrights Shaped in One Crucible,'' Sept. 24)], and they all concluded that writing itself, not recognition, provides the greatest satisfaction.

When Signature Theater honors a single writer over an entire season, it bestows a sort of Olympian status on that individual. Jesse McKinley interviewed five of these chosen dramatists [''A Reunion of Playwrights Shaped in One Crucible,'' Sept. 24)], and they all concluded that writing itself, not recognition, provides the greatest satisfaction.

In Greek mythology, when mortals challenge the gods, they get turned into spiders, dolphins or constellations. Yet when one has something substantive to offer, he gets a throne on the mountaintop. Dionysus makes wine. Gods like wine. Dionysus is in.

Struggling playwrights who cringe and imagine seasons of our own on Signature's Mount Olympus would do well to remember: we've got to plant vines, grow grapes, harvest, press, bottle, ferment and age. All hard work. For heaven's sake, let's enjoy the work. Apparently it's the best part.
The writer is a playwright whose first Off Broadway production, ''Tabletop,'' opens in October at the American Place Theater.
